titleInfo.title: Describing the Morphological Complexity of Teachers' Spoken Language
titleInfo.subTitle: Comparisons across Four Instructional Subjects

name.namePart: School of Communication Science and Disorders

mods:mods.abstract: Morphology has a unique role in reading due to the morphophonemic structure of English (Venezky, 1967). Morphemes exist as the smallest meaningful unit of language (Carlisle, 2003) and connect orthographical patterns to phonological representations and semantic meanings (Kirby & Bowers, 2017; Perfetti, 2007). Accordingly, morphological awareness (MA), or the ability to understand and use morphemes (Carlisle, 2003), has an important role in both decoding and reading comprehension according to multiple theories and frameworks (e.g., Kirby & Bowers, 2017; Levesque et al., 2021; Perfetti & Stafura, 2014). In academic reading, MA is particularly crucial due to the large amount of complex polymorphemic words in academic vocabulary (Nagy & Anderson, 1984). MA and morphological instruction have been empirically tied to reading skills for K-12 students, including vulnerable populations such as English language learners (ELLs) or students with learning disabilities (LD) (Goodwin & Ahn, 2013; Lee et al., 2023). During elementary school, when students' derivational MA is still developing (Carlisle & Stone, 2005; Kuo & Andrson, 2006), sources of language input include both print and spoken language. While some studies have investigated the vocabulary content of teachers' spoken language input (Hollo & Wehby, 2017; Wanzek et al., 2022, 2023), there is a dearth of literature examining the morphological complexity (MC) of teachers' instructional dialogues. To address this gap in the literature, the current study asked two questions: (1) What types and frequencies of affixes occur in teachers' instructional dialogues as described by Bauer and Nation's (1993) Levels of morphological complexity? (2) How do types, frequencies, and proportions of affixes occurring in teachers' instructional dialogues as described by Bauer and Nation's (1993) Levels differ by instructional subject? This study examined fifteen-minute transcriptions (n = 1494) of teachers' (n = 40) dialogues occurring during four instructional subjects—English Language Arts (ELA), math, science, and social science—using Morpholex, an online affix profiler (Cobb, 2023). Morpholex generated descriptive statistics on the frequency of base words, inflections, and derivations. The profiler provided further information on affix characteristics by categorizing morphemes into Bauer and Nations' (1993) Levels. Results found that frequencies of inflectional and derivational morphemes differed between subjects but were low across the sample. Implications for instruction and future research are discussed.
mods:mods.note: A Thesis submitted to the Department of Communication Science and Disorders in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Science.
language, morphology, reading, subject, teacher, vocabulary
Sana T. Tibi, Professor Directing Thesis; Carla L. Wood, Committee Member; Shannon S. J. Hall-Mills, Committee Member; Christopher W. Schatschneider, Committee Member.
